DOC.HEAD: Rolls-Royce Workers End Strike After Winning 37-Hour Work Week
DOC.TEXT: Rolls-Royce PLC, a maker of aviation engines, cut its work week from 39 to 37 hours to end a six-week strike by 2,000 engineering workers at its Glasgow plant. The workers voted by a 3-1 majority Saturday in favor of a management offer to gradually reduce the basic work week to 37 hours by November 1991, Rolls-Royce and union leaders said. They return to work Monday. In return, local unions agreed to greater flexibility on working practices and job training to prevent a falloff in productivity at the plant. Engineering unions have brought 10,000 workers out on strike since mid-October in a selective campaign to shorten the standard 39-hour British work week for its 2 million members in 5,000 companies. Agreement on a 37-hour work week by 1992 has already been negotiated at two other engineering companies, Smiths Industries PLC of Cheltenham and NEI-Parsons of Newcastle-upon-Tyne. More than 7,000 manual workers at three British Aerospace PLC plants in England have been on strike since mid-October in an effort to win a 35-hour week.
